awd_abstract_narration:
The EvaluATE Center is an ATE Support Center dedicated to supporting and improving the evaluation practices of approximately 250 ATE grantees across the country. EvaluATE conducts webinars and workshops, blogs on evaluation practice, maintains a website with a digital resource library, develops materials to guide evaluation work, and conducts an annual survey of ATE grantees. EvaluATE's mission is to promote the goals of the ATE program by partnering with projects and centers to strengthen the program's evaluation knowledge base, expand the use of exemplary evaluation practices, and support the continuous improvement of technician education throughout the nation. EvaluATE's goals associated with this proposal are to: (1) Ensure that all ATE Principal Investigators and evaluators know the essential elements of a credible and useful evaluation; (2) Maintain a comprehensive collection of online resources for ATE evaluation; (3) Strengthen and expand the network of ATE evaluation stakeholders; and (4) Gather, synthesize, and disseminate data about the ATE program activities to advance knowledge about ATE/technician education. The Center plans to produce a comprehensive set of evaluation resources to complement other services, engaging several community college-based Principal Investigators, representatives from selected community colleges, and evaluators in that process. 

EvaluATE's products are informed by current research on evaluation, the National Science Foundation's priorities for the evaluation of ATE grants, and the needs of ATE PIs and evaluators for sound guidance that is immediately relevant and usable in their contexts. The fundamental nature of EvaluATE's work is geared toward supporting ATE grantees to use evaluation regularly to improve their work and demonstrate their impacts. All of EvaluATE's products are available to the public. EvaluATE's findings from the annual survey of ATE grantees aid in advancing understanding of the status of technician education and illuminate areas for additional research. Implementing a mixed methods research design the Center will investigate approaches and methods to assess the impact of activities associated with developing evaluation capacity building

por.por_cntn:
EvaluATE is the evaluation support center for NSF’s Advanced Technological Education (ATE) program. EvaluATE’s mission is to support the pursuit of excellence in advanced technological education by strengthening the ATE program’s evaluation and knowledge base, expanding the use of state-of-the-art evaluation practices, and supporting the continuous improvement of technician education throughout the nation.

EvaluATE’s goals are to (1) support ATE community members to achieve competency as evaluators and evaluation consumers, (2) develop and disseminate resources to improve ATE evaluation practices, (3) strengthen and expand the network of ATE community members involved in evaluation, and (4) monitor the ATE program’s activities and achievements and disseminate that information to the ATE community and beyond.

Under this grant, from 2016 to 2021, EvaluATE developed 23 webinars, 10 workshops, 23 short videos, 31 conference presentations, 9 roundtable sessions, 3 published peer-reviewed articles, 1 white paper, 26 newsletters, 5 annual surveys of ATE principal investigators (PIs), and 22 ATE Survey reports. We engaged over 3,970 people in our live training and community activities internal and external to the ATE community. Many more were reached through our resource materials, website, blogs, and recordings. Our most accessed resources include a Creating One-Page Reports worksheet, Tips And Tricks for Designing in PowerPoint, an Evaluation Data Matrix Template, and the ATE Proposal Evaluation Plan Template

EvaluATE’s intellectual merit under this grant is demonstrated by our publications on advancing research in the ATE community, developing and using project vitae for knowledge management, assessing evaluation capacity building through artifacts, and identifying barriers to collecting and reporting data on student participation. EvaluATE also continued to administer and report findings from the annual survey of ATE PIs, which has an average response rate of 90% and generates data about the activities and achievements of ATE projects. EvaluATE also collaborated with seven ATE projects to contribute to applied research in areas such as industry collaboration, accessibility conditions in ATE projects, future trends and challenges in advanced technological education, and mathematics requirements.

EvaluATE’s broader impacts under this grant include increased evaluation capacity of ATE project staff and evaluators, as well as stronger connections among those who value and engage in evaluation efforts. Through internal and external evaluation activities, EvaluATE assesses its impact on five levels of outcomes (Kirkpatrick & Kirkpatrick, 2006): reach, satisfaction, learning, application, and impact.

  • Reach: Between 2016 and 2021, EvaluATE reached 3,972 unique individuals through training and community activities and events. This included ATE project staff, evaluators, and grant specialists, along with project staff and evaluators outside of the ATE community. Attendees came from two- and four-year colleges; local, state, and federal agencies (both domestic and foreign); nonprofit organizations; research and evaluation firms; multilateral agencies; K–12 schools; national professional associations; and business and industry.
  • Satisfaction: Overall, people were highly satisfied with EvaluATE’s services and found our trainings useful. Eighty-four percent of EvaluATE survey respondents rated the overall quality of EvaluATE’s information as excellent or very good, according to a survey in 2020 (n=263). Eighty-three percent of users shared EvaluATE’s resources with someone else, a testament to the utility and quality of EvaluATE’s materials.
  • Learning: EvaluATE’s users report increased understanding of evaluation practices on webinar and workshop feedback forms, as well as in external evaluation surveys. Over 90% of survey respondents from the ATE community reported an improvement in their understanding of specific aspects of evaluation due to information received via EvaluATE, such as what NSF and other funders expect from evaluation, what should be included in evaluation plans, and what to expect from an evaluator (according to a survey in 2020, n=153).
  • Application: Ideally, learning about evaluation translates into improved practices. Over 50% of survey respondents from the ATE community reported that EvaluATE had a moderate or large influence on their work in terms of considering evaluation results more when making decisions about their project, integrating evaluation more fully into their projects, and reflecting on their evaluation practice (according to a survey in 2020, n=135).
  • Impact: To obtain a more objective view of EvaluATE’s impact on evaluation practice in the ATE community, EvaluATE’s external evaluation team reviewed a random sample of 169 proposals funded by the ATE program between 2004 and 2017. Findings from this study showed that ATE proposal evaluation plans in 2017 are more likely to include key elements of a high-quality evaluation plan¾elements encouraged by EvaluATE resources and training. These include identification of who will lead the evaluation (and their qualifications); what information will be collected; how the data will be analyzed and/or how findings will be used to answer the evaluation questions; and how, when, and to whom the evaluation results will be communicated. This improvement in evaluation plans over time corroborates EvaluATE users’ self-reports of EvaluATE’s positive influence on the evaluation capacity of the ATE community.

 


Last Modified: 12/23/2021
Modified by: Lyssa W Becho

EvaluATE’s mission is to support the pursuit of excellence in advanced technological education by strengthening the ATE program’s evaluation and knowledge base, expanding the use of state-of-the-art evaluation practices, and supporting the continuous improvement of technician education throughout the nation.

Many more were reached through our resource materials, website, blogs, and recordings. EvaluATE’s intellectual merit under this grant is demonstrated by our publications on advancing research in the ATE community, developing and using project vitae for knowledge management, assessing evaluation capacity building through artifacts, and identifying barriers to collecting and reporting data on student participation.
